The Pros and Cons of Expressways

3. Automobile driving along regular city streets is usually a rather
dreary and dismal experience. Driving on urban expressways is
often stimulating and even exciting. Not only is there the

“ pleasure of being able to proceed continuously and at good speeds
through highly congested areas, but also expressways sometimes
can provide the opportunity for interesting and even spectacular
views of the city. The expressway running along the west side of
Manhattan Island in- New York City is a good example. At the
upper end are magnificent vistas of the Hudson River and the
Palisades on the opposite shore. Further down are intimate
close-ups of the great trans-Atlantic liners as well as views of the
skyscraper concentrations at midtown and on lower Manhattan
Island. Here in Baltimore the approaches to the Harbor Tunnel
afford new and unusual vantage points from which to see the

harbor and the center of the City. Expressway driving in many

"\cases can be an exhilarating experience.

Costs

There are wide variations in expressway costs. One of the most
expensive was the Central Artery in Boston which cost about $36,000,000
per mile. About one-quarter of this cost was for right of way. At the
other end of the scale is the Cabrillo Freeway in San Diego which was
completed in 1949 at an average cost of $768,000 per mile. In this case
right of way costs were negligible.

A short elevated expressway close to the central business district of
San Francisco ran $16,000,000 per mile, while in Chicago the eight-mile
depressed Congress Street expressway was built for about $12,500,000
per mile.

In view of the great variations in expressway costs it is not possible
to generalize beyond noting that any expressway through developed urban
areas will be expensive.

A certain amount of research has been done to demonstrate that
expressways produce sufficient savings to justify their initial costs. For
example, according to studies conducted in Los Angeles, the average saving
from expressway use came to 2.0 cents per vehicle mile, computed as
follows:

BT VT P R SIS L A 0.33 cents
Vehicle maintenance cost savings due to

elimination of stop-and-go travel............... 0.24 cents
ROCICOBL WRVINEE el o v s e kW s o b e e 0.56 cents
Commercial vehicle time savings

Cotoratnd to ol BB i o ini o i s pnnig 0.87 cents

In 1954, 46 miles of Los Angeles expressway, completed at a cost of
$198,000,000, carried 1.2 billion miles of vehicle travel. The apparent
saving at 2.0 cents per mile totaled $24,000,000 or enough to equal con-
struction cost in eight years. Studies in other cities show similar results.

It may be held that these figures should not be taken too literally
if only on the basis that no self-respecting government agency is ever
without a similar justification for the program which it is administering.
Be that as it may, it is probable that this type of statistical analysis
should be qualified to some extent.

It should be noted first of all that these savings accumulate in little
bits and pieces for a large number of individuals and for this reason are
largely unnoticed. Any individual making a ten-mile expressway trip
will be highly conscious of the time saved and the pleasure added, but he
certainly will not tell himself that he has just saved 215 cents in mainte-
nance costs. The owner of a fleet of trucks will undoubtedly be able to
